newsitem.title: USA: Three firefighters killed in Arkansas explosion.
newsitem.headline: Three firefighters killed in Arkansas explosion.

text.p: Three firefighters were killed and more than a dozen injured battling an explosion and fire that released toxic fumes at an Arkansas chemical plant Thursday, emergency officials said.
"It's bad. I don't know how much worse it's going to get. I'm not sure anybody knows right now," Arkansas State Police spokesman Wayne Jordan said.
The explosion released azinphos-methyl, an insecticide that attacks the central nervous system and is used as a pesticide and to control mites, a hazardous materials expert said.

Brief exposures can generate symptoms ranging from breathing problems to paralysis. Longer exposures could cause permanent, degenerative damage to the central nervous system, University of Houston chemist James Cox said.
"If I were exposed to it I would regard it as exceedingly hazardous," Cox said.
The explosion at the BPS Co. chemical plant in northeast Arkansas released an "unknown quantity of toxic gas" into the air, Arkansas Office of Emergency Services spokeswoman Francis Huddleston said.
